awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Biometric Wearable Device for Real-Time Mental Health Intervention of Anxiety
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to utilize artificial intelligence for mental health interventions, with an initial application of college students.   Over 60% of U.S. college students suffer stress and anxiety that can manifest in physical symptoms such as palpitations, chest pressure, stomach aches, muscular tension, diarrhea/constipation, and fatigue. The significant negative impact of stress and anxiety affects learning, development, and social engagement, and ultimately can contribute to destructive behaviors such as drug and alcohol use. This project proposes an intelligent, personalized digital health technology that integrates biometrics for automated, early detection of increasingly stressed states as a cost-effective way to inform interventions and improve college retention. This application can be expanded to other populations for improved mental health outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project improves mental health through integration of wearable biometric sensors, artificial intelligence (AI), and a user interface to guide both automated and interactive psychotherapy interventions. A wearable wrist band device will passively capture biosignals to detect signals of anxiety to inform an automated analysis.  The app can then provide varying levels of alerts and intervention as appropriate for the magnitude of the event. This can be used for mental health monitoring broadly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Research was completed to develop and demonstrate the feasibility of Innsightful, an AI-driven platform to automatically detect personalized negative stressful events via a wearable device and decrease stress and anxiety in college students. Currently, 70.5% of college students report academic performance is affected by stress; 53.1% are affected by anxiety, and 34.5% by depression. Serious psychological distress has increased 71% among young adults. Student use of counseling centers increased 40% recently but colleges have no on-campus psychiatric support or long wait times are extremely long, and many students end up in crisis. In 2018, more than half of college counseling centers and psychiatric centers reported needing more hours to meet student demand. The most common mental health issues among college students are anxiety, depression, relationship issues, and thoughts of suicide. Sadly, only half receive treatment, partially due to significant stigma around mental health. These mental health service and accessible treatment path shortages result in a mental health crisis on U.S. college campuses is significant and growing. For these reasons the Innsightful platform targets 18-25 age users and based on the results presented a successful intervention.

The Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project included platform updates, a data collection and usability study, and subsequent algorithm development and validation.  First, the existing platform was updated to integrate additional sensor such as heart rate variability and SPO2 level.  We improved the platform UI and tested it extensively. We also incorporated a wearable device. Once the prototype passed internal testing, the data collection and usability in both laboratory and field setting was conducted. The Users reported fewer than 1 technical issue per user with the wearable device, and they achieve average usability score of greater than 3. the AI utilized algorithm demonstrated 86% sensitivity and 93% specificity. 

The data collection and identification of stressors has been comprehensively tested and the results showed the Innsightful technology can be effective. As the wearable detects stress the app will provide a combination of just-in-time activities including pre-selected positive activities and interventions to mitigate events in real-time.  Initial testing of the just in time activities showed significant reductions in anxiety and depression as measured by standard self-report tools.  The results of accurately identifying stress, anxiety and depression; the higher-than-expected usability result; and the effectiveness just in time activities provides the basis for reducing the mental health crisis on US college campuses.


Last Modified: 02/04/2023
Modified by: Farzad Ehsani
